newsitem.title: USA: Los Angeles trade up 3.6 percent in 1996 - report.
newsitem.headline: Los Angeles trade up 3.6 percent in 1996 - report.

text.p: International trade through the Los Angeles customs district rose 3.6 percent to $170.1 billion in 1996, according to a report Thursday.
Los Angeles remained the busiest customs district in the nation, outpacing New York, where trade was up 4.1 percent to $155.8 billion, the CMC-Tradeweek Regional Trade Report said.

Detroit and San Francisco, third and fourth in total volume, also posted increases in 1996. Detroit trade was up 7.4 percent to $129.6 billion. San Francisco posted a 2.7 percent increase to $105.5 billion in trade, the report said.
Trade with China fueled much of Los Angeles' trade growth, jumping 16.3 percent to $21.2 billion, the report said.
Japan continued to be Los Angeles' top export destination, with more than $16 billion in volume. Imports from Japan fell 4.6 percent to $29.4 billion, the report said.

Pacific Rim nations were Los Angeles' top trading partners in 1996. Japan topped the list, followed by China, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore. Germany was the top non-Pacific Rim trading partner with $4 billion in volume.
Top exports from Los Angeles included computer circuits and parts, aircraft, cotton, cars and auto parts.
Top imports included computers and parts, cars, telephone and office equipment, footwear and consumer electronics, the report said.
The CMC-Tradeweek Regional Trade Report is jointly published by Claremont McKenna College and TradeWeek. The report monitors international trade and its impact on the Los Angeles area economy.

The trade data was derived from import and export declarations filed by traders shipping goods through the Los Angeles customs district. The district includes the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach, Los Angeles International Airport and ports in Ventura County and Las Vegas.
